Official Claims vs. Reality

Official Claims vs. Reality

Section titled â€œOfficial Claims vs. Realityâ€

They promised transparency.
FOI revealed they kept no records.

This page documents five systematic contradictions between official government statements and FOI-proven reality.

Each contradiction follows the same pattern:

  1. Official claim made in legislation, FAQ, or parliamentary speech
  2. FOI request seeks evidence the claim was implemented
  3. Section 26 response: â€œNo documents existâ€
  4. Conclusion: Either the promise was never implemented, or government deliberately avoided documentation

This is not advocacy. This is archival comparison of governmentâ€™s own words.

Contradiction 1: AWACâ€™s Phantom Oversight

Section titled â€œContradiction 1: AWACâ€™s Phantom Oversightâ€

ğŸ“˜ Official Promise (September 2021)

Section titled â€œğŸ“˜ Official Promise (September 2021)â€

Source: Animal Welfare Advisory Committee Terms of Reference

Quote:

â€œThe AWAC will advise the Minister, when requested to do so or on its own initiative, in relation to:

  • the development and implementation of standards relevant to training and competency assessment of appointed inspectors under the Act; and
  • animal welfare research.â€

â€œAWAC will provide an annual report to the Minister by 31 October, which includes matters discussed, advice provided, research supported and activities undertaken.â€

ğŸ“„ AWAC Terms of Reference

ğŸ•³ï¸ FOI Reality (October 2025)

Section titled â€œğŸ•³ï¸ FOI Reality (October 2025)â€

Source: FOI2025-017 Internal Review Decision

DPIRDâ€™s Section 26 determination:

â€œFollowing reasonable searches of the Department, I have determined under section 26 of the FOI Act that documents do not exist in respect to:

  • How the Animal Welfare Advisory Committee (AWAC) has overseen the oversight of Designated Inspectors under the Animal Welfare Act
  • Records of AWAC discussions regarding Designated Inspector oversight
  • Any reports, recommendations, or meeting minutes where AWAC reviewed DI training standards, performance, or compliance monitoringâ€

Timeline:

  • AWAC established: February 2022
  • DI system created: April 2023
  • FOI request: July 2025
  • Result: Zero oversight documents exist for 3.5-year period

ğŸ“„ FOI2025-017 Internal Review Decision

ğŸ” Analysis

Section titled â€œğŸ” Analysisâ€

Mandated function: AWAC Terms of Reference explicitly require oversight of inspector training and competency standards.

Highest-risk enforcement mechanism: Designated Inspectors (DIs) are the only legal witnesses inside intensive animal facilities since filming was criminalized.

Complete absence: Despite 2.5 years of DI operation (April 2023 â€“ October 2025), AWAC has produced:

  • âˆ… Zero meeting minutes discussing DI oversight
  • âˆ… Zero annual reports mentioning DI compliance
  • âˆ… Zero training standards developed for DI program
  • âˆ… Zero evidence of â€œindependent oversightâ€ function

Structural meaning: AWAC exists as oversight theatreâ€”a committee with no enforcement power that produces no documented oversight of the highest-risk enforcement program created in 25 years.

Contradiction 2: The Training That Never Was

Section titled â€œContradiction 2: The Training That Never Wasâ€

ğŸ“˜ Official Promise (2023)

Section titled â€œğŸ“˜ Official Promise (2023)â€

Source: DPIRD FAQ â€“ Animal Welfare and Trespass Legislation Changes

Quote:

â€œDesignated inspectors have received extensive training in investigations as well as specialised training in respect of livestock. They are professionals who act in accordance with DPIRDâ€™s processes and procedures.â€

â€œDPIRD ensures that all inspectors are appropriately skilled, trained and supported to carry out their functions under the Animal Welfare Act.â€

â€œWhen suitably trained and appointed, designated inspectors will begin carrying out a risk-based, proactive inspection regime to monitor compliance with the Animal Welfare Act at intensive production places, abattoirs and knackeries.â€

ğŸ“„ Trespass Legislation FAQ (2023)

ğŸ•³ï¸ FOI Reality (October 2025)

Section titled â€œğŸ•³ï¸ FOI Reality (October 2025)â€

Source: FOI2025-017 Internal Review Decision

DPIRDâ€™s Section 26 determination:

â€œFollowing reasonable searches of the Department, I have determined under section 26 of the FOI Act that documents do not exist in respect to:

  • Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for Designated Inspectors
  • Training protocols or training records specific to DI functions
  • Risk assessment frameworks for facility selection
  • Compliance monitoring procedures
  • Performance metrics for DI programâ€

Source: FOI2025-008 â€“ Facility Inspection Data (2022-2025)

Documented inspections (3-year period):

  • Piggeries: 20 inspections
  • Poultry farms: 14 inspections
  • Rabbit farms: 1 inspection
  • Total intensive production facilities: 35 inspections over 3 years

Average: ~12 intensive facility inspections per year across entire state

ğŸ“„ FOI2025-017 Internal Review Decision
ğŸ“„ FOI Document 1 â€“ Inspection Summary

ğŸ” Analysis

Section titled â€œğŸ” Analysisâ€

Claim: â€œExtensive trainingâ€ + â€œprocesses and proceduresâ€ + â€œrisk-based proactive regimeâ€

Reality:

  • No SOPs exist = no â€œprocesses and proceduresâ€
  • No training records exist = no evidence of â€œextensive trainingâ€
  • 12 inspections/year â‰  â€œproactive regimeâ€ for thousands of facilities

Logical outcomes:

  1. DIs received no specialized training (contradicts FAQ)
  2. DIs received training but DPIRD kept no records (administrative failure)
  3. DIs were trained, but training was so inadequate DPIRD wonâ€™t document it (liability avoidance)

All three possibilities indicate systematic dysfunction.

Legal significance: The FAQ was published to justify the 2023 Trespass Law to Parliament and the public. If its core claims are unsupported by documentation, the lawâ€™s transparency justification collapses.

Contradiction 3: The 52 Recommendations Betrayal

Section titled â€œContradiction 3: The 52 Recommendations Betrayalâ€

ğŸ“˜ Official Promise (June 2021)

Section titled â€œğŸ“˜ Official Promise (June 2021)â€

Source: WA Government Response to Independent Review of Animal Welfare Act 2002

Quote:

â€œThe McGowan Government generally accepts the findings of the Review and supports the recommendations.â€

Recommendation 12:

â€œInspectors monitoring compliance with the Act and regulations in a particular animal sector must have met specified training standards and demonstrated competency relevant to the animal species/industry sector in which they perform their regulatory functions.â€

Government response: â€œSupportedâ€

Recommendation 26:

â€œA specified standard of training and competency for animal welfare inspectors and authorised officers be developed and maintained, and its maintenance overseen by an independent body.â€

Government response: â€œSupportedâ€

ğŸ“„ Government Response to 2020 Review
ğŸ“„ Independent Review 2020 (Full Report)

ğŸ•³ï¸ Parliamentary Reality (September 2025)

Section titled â€œğŸ•³ï¸ Parliamentary Reality (September 2025)â€

Quote:

â€œIt has now been more than four years since the 2020 review of the Animal Welfare Act delivered 52 recommendations to modernise this framework, and even though the recommendations were supported by this very government, none have yet been enacted.â€

â€œThe 2020 review of the Animal Welfare Act confirmed this, finding that the RSPCA bears significant prosecuting and enforcement costs beyond its capacity. Despite these findings and the governmentâ€™s stated support for reform, we are still waiting for action.â€

ğŸ“„ Hansard â€“ Chief Animal Protection Officer Bill (2025)

Section titled â€œğŸ•³ï¸ FOI Reality (October 2025)â€

DPIRDâ€™s Section 26 determination:

â€œFollowing reasonable searches of the Department, I have determined under section 26 of the FOI Act that documents do not exist in respect to:

  • Implementation of 2020 Review Recommendation 12 (training standards)
  • Implementation of 2020 Review Recommendation 26 (independent oversight of training)
  • Any training standards or competency frameworks developed post-2020 Reviewâ€

ğŸ“„ FOI2025-017 Internal Review Decision

ğŸ” Analysis

Section titled â€œğŸ” Analysisâ€

Promise made: June 2021
Independent expert review: 18 months of consultation, 52 evidence-based recommendations
Government commitment: â€œSupportedâ€

Implementation status (October 2025):

  • 52 recommendations supported
  • Zero recommendations enacted
  • Specifically for inspector training (Rec 12 & 26): no evidence of any implementation attempt

Timeline of betrayal:

  • 2020: Review identifies training gaps
  • 2021: Government â€œsupportsâ€ fixing them
  • 2023: Government creates DI system without implementing training reforms
  • 2025: FOI confirms training standards still donâ€™t exist

Structural meaning: Government used 2020 Review as political theatre to claim theyâ€™re â€œlistening to experts.â€ Then ignored every recommendation while creating a new high-risk enforcement mechanism (DI system) that embodies the exact problems the Review identified.

Parliamentary consequence: Hon Amanda Dorn (Animal Justice Party) was forced to introduce a private memberâ€™s bill (Chief Animal Protection Officer Bill 2025) to attempt reforms government promised 4 years ago.

Contradiction 4: Transparency as Trespass Justification

Section titled â€œContradiction 4: Transparency as Trespass Justificationâ€

ğŸ“˜ Official Promise (April 2023)

Section titled â€œğŸ“˜ Official Promise (April 2023)â€

Source: Attorney General John Quigley, Media Statement on Trespass Law

Quote:

â€œBy enhancing the existing animal welfare inspection regime, animal advocates will no longer be able to use lack of transparency in abattoirs and other intensive production facilities as a reason for their illegal actions.â€

â€œThe Governmentâ€™s new laws strike a balance between protecting our agricultural sector and ensuring that the community can have confidence in the animal welfare practices employed by the sector.â€

â€œOffenders who illegally enter a premise used for commercial animal farming or slaughter now face a maximum penalty of $24,000 and two yearsâ€™ imprisonment, an increase from $12,000 and 12 months.â€

ğŸ“„ Government Media Statement (April 2023)

Source: DPIRD FAQ (2023)

Quote:

â€œThe Amending Act enables DPIRD to implement a proactive modern compliance and inspection regime by giving appointed designated inspectors increased powers of entry under the AW Act.â€

â€œThe new powers should give the community confidence that DPIRD inspectors are monitoring compliance with animal welfare legislation at high-risk facilities.â€

ğŸ“„ Trespass Legislation FAQ (2023)

ğŸ•³ï¸ FOI Reality (2025)

Section titled â€œğŸ•³ï¸ FOI Reality (2025)â€

Source: FOI2025-008 â€“ Inspection Data (2022-2025)

Intensive production facility inspections (3-year period):

  • Piggeries: 20 inspections
  • Poultry farms: 14 inspections
  • Rabbit farms: 1 inspection
  • Total: 35 inspections

Context:

  • WA has hundreds of intensive production facilities
  • Average: ~12 intensive facility inspections per year statewide
  • No evidence of inspection frequency increasing post-April 2023 (DI legislation)

ğŸ“„ FOI Document 1 â€“ Inspection Summary

Source: FOI2025-017 â€“ DI Oversight

DPIRDâ€™s Section 26 determination:

â€œDocuments do not existâ€ for:

  • DI proactive inspection schedules
  • Compliance monitoring frameworks
  • Risk-based facility prioritization protocols
  • DI performance metrics or outcome data

ğŸ“„ FOI2025-017 Internal Review Decision

ğŸ” Analysis

Section titled â€œğŸ” Analysisâ€

The bargain presented to Parliament and public:

  • Give up: Right to film/document inside facilities (criminalized via doubled trespass penalties)
  • Get back: Government-provided transparency through â€œproactiveâ€ DI inspections

What was actually delivered:

  • âœ“ Trespass penalties doubled ($24,000 + 2 years prison) â€“ Delivered
  • âœ“ Filming/whistleblowing criminalized â€“ Delivered
  • âœ— â€œProactive modern compliance regimeâ€ â€“ No evidence exists
  • âœ— â€œEnhanced inspection regimeâ€ â€“ 12 inspections/year for thousands of facilities
  • âœ— Community â€œconfidenceâ€ â€“ Based on false premises

Timeline of deception:

  • April 2023: Law passes with transparency justification
  • April 2023 â€“ July 2025: 2+ years of DI system operation
  • July 2025: FOI reveals no systematic oversight exists

Legal significance: The trespass lawâ€™s public justification was false at the time of enactment, or government knew it would not deliver the promised oversight. Either way, Parliament and public were misled.

Outcome: Agricultural industry received legal protection from scrutiny. Animals and whistleblowers received criminalization. Promised government transparency: non-existent.

Contradiction 5: â€œModern Compliance Regimeâ€ Fiction

Section titled â€œContradiction 5: â€œModern Compliance Regimeâ€ Fictionâ€

ğŸ“˜ Official Promise (2023)

Section titled â€œğŸ“˜ Official Promise (2023)â€

Source: DPIRD FAQ â€“ Animal Welfare and Trespass Legislation Changes

Quote:

â€œThe Amending Act enables DPIRD to implement a proactive modern compliance and inspection regime by giving appointed designated inspectors increased powers of entry under the AW Act.â€

â€œDesignated inspectors will be able to enter abattoirs, knackeries and places they believe on reasonable grounds to be intensive production places, at any time, without prior notice.â€

â€œThe operation of a modern and effective compliance monitoring regime requires that designated inspectors can proactively inspect such places to ensure animals are being treated humanely and in accordance with relevant codes of practice and animal welfare standards.â€

â€œDPIRD ensures that all inspectors are appropriately skilled, trained and supported to carry out their functions under the Animal Welfare Act and its regulations. Designated inspectors have received extensive training in investigations as well as specialised training in respect of livestock.â€

ğŸ“„ Trespass Legislation FAQ (2023)

ğŸ•³ï¸ FOI Reality (October 2025)

Section titled â€œğŸ•³ï¸ FOI Reality (October 2025)â€

Source: FOI2025-017 Internal Review Decision

DPIRDâ€™s Section 26 determination:

â€œFollowing reasonable searches of the Department, I have determined under section 26 of the FOI Act that documents do not exist in respect to:

  • No compliance monitoring framework documents
  • No risk assessment protocols for facility selection
  • No inspection scheduling system records
  • No performance metrics for DI program
  • No outcome tracking for DI inspections
  • No quality assurance processes documented
  • No public reporting mechanisms establishedâ€

ğŸ“„ FOI2025-017 Internal Review Decision

Source: FOI2025-008 â€“ Inspection Data

Actual inspection frequency (2022-2025):

  • Average: 23 facility inspections per year (all types)
  • Intensive production: ~12 inspections per year
  • No evidence of increase post-DI legislation (April 2023)

Comparison:

  • Claimed: â€œProactive modern compliance regimeâ€ + â€œat any timeâ€ entry
  • Reality: 12 inspections/year for hundreds of facilities + no documented system

ğŸ“„ FOI Document 1 â€“ Inspection Summary

ğŸ” Analysis

Section titled â€œğŸ” Analysisâ€

What â€œmodern compliance regimeâ€ requires:

  1. Risk assessment framework (identify highest-risk facilities)
  2. Inspection scheduling system (ensure coverage)
  3. Performance metrics (track outcomes)
  4. Quality assurance (ensure consistency)
  5. Public reporting (enable accountability)
  6. Training standards (ensure competency)

What FOI revealed exists:

  • âˆ… None of the above

FAQ claimed: â€œProactive modern compliance and inspection regimeâ€

Reality: No evidence of:

  • Proactivity (no risk-based scheduling)
  • Modernity (no data systems documented)
  • Compliance monitoring (no outcome tracking)
  • Inspection regime (12 inspections/year â‰  systematic regime)

Core contradiction:

The FAQ promises DIs will ensure animals are â€œbeing treated humanely and in accordance with relevant codes of practice.â€ But FOI proves:

  • No systematic inspection schedule exists
  • No compliance monitoring framework exists
  • No way to verify if animals are treated in accordance with any standards

Structural meaning: Government created legal powers (â€œat any timeâ€ entry) without creating operational systems to use those powers systematically. This is not implementation failureâ€”it is deliberate non-implementation disguised as reform.

The Pattern: Systematic Deception

Section titled â€œThe Pattern: Systematic Deceptionâ€

These five contradictions share a common structure:

Stage 1: Create Oversight Bodies

Section titled â€œStage 1: Create Oversight Bodiesâ€
  • 2022: Establish AWAC with inspector oversight mandate
  • 2023: Create DI system with â€œproactive inspectionâ€ powers

Stage 2: Make Public Assurances

Section titled â€œStage 2: Make Public Assurancesâ€
  • Publish FAQs claiming â€œextensive trainingâ€
  • Release media statements guaranteeing â€œtransparencyâ€
  • â€œSupportâ€ all 52 review recommendations

Stage 3: Implement Nothing

Section titled â€œStage 3: Implement Nothingâ€
  • No SOPs created
  • No AWAC oversight activated
  • No training standards implemented
  • No 2020 Review recommendations enacted

Stage 4: Use Fake Oversight to Justify Repression

Section titled â€œStage 4: Use Fake Oversight to Justify Repressionâ€
  • Double trespass penalties justified by DI â€œtransparencyâ€
  • Criminalize whistleblowing while providing zero alternative accountability
  • Cite â€œmodern compliance regimeâ€ that doesnâ€™t exist

Why This Matters

Section titled â€œWhy This Mattersâ€

The 2023 Trespass Law was presented to Parliament and the public as a balanced compromise:

Trade-off claimed:

  • Citizens give up right to document conditions inside facilities
  • Government provides transparency through DI inspections
  • Result: animal welfare protected, agriculture sector protected

Trade-off delivered:

  • Citizens face $24,000 fines + 2 years prison for filming
  • Government provides ~12 inspections/year with no documented oversight system
  • Result: Systemic opacity protected by law

This means:

  1. Public was deceived: Community told intensive facilities would be monitored â€œat any timeâ€â€”they are not
  2. Parliament was misled: Legislation passed based on assurances of â€œmodern compliance regimeâ€â€”no such regime exists
  3. Industry got cover: Agricultural sector received legal protection from scrutiny without corresponding accountability
  4. Animals got nothing: 25 years of legislative promises produced zero systematic enforcement improvement

Legal & Ethical Implications

Section titled â€œLegal & Ethical Implicationsâ€

For Government Accountability

Section titled â€œFor Government Accountabilityâ€

When government publishes official FAQs making factual claims (â€œextensive training,â€ â€œproactive regimeâ€), those claims create reasonable public expectations. If FOI reveals those claims are unsupported by any documentation, government has:

  1. Made materially false statements to justify legislation
  2. Created oversight theatre while maintaining structural opacity
  3. Used false transparency promises to criminalize actual transparency efforts

For Legislative Integrity

Section titled â€œFor Legislative Integrityâ€

Parliament passed the 2023 Trespass Law based on government assurances that DI system would provide oversight. If those assurances were false, the lawâ€™s foundational justification collapses.

This is not about whether the law is â€œgoodâ€ or â€œbad.â€ It is about whether the law was passed under false premises.

For Public Trust

Section titled â€œFor Public Trustâ€

As Hon Amanda Dorn stated (18 Sept 2025):

â€œThis is proof that animal welfare has not been given priority by the government, despite overwhelming community expectations for stronger, independent and transparent protections.â€

When 4,043 citizens petition Parliament (Sept 2025) for reforms promised in 2021, and government response is to maintain oversight theatre while criminalizing documentation, public trust becomes impossible.

What FOI Archaeology Reveals

Section titled â€œWhat FOI Archaeology Revealsâ€

For 25 years, government made promises in Hansard, media releases, and official FAQs.

For 25 years, no one could prove whether those promises were keptâ€”because enforcement data was never published.

Then Freedom of Information requests asked:
â€œShow us the documents proving you did what you said.â€

And government responded:
â€œNo documents exist.â€

The absence is the evidence.

The void is the finding.

The refusal to record is the policy.

Documentation Standard
Every claim on this page is sourced to:

  • Official government documents (legislation, FAQs, media statements)
  • Parliamentary records (Hansard)
  • FOI responses (Section 26 determinations, notices of decision)

All quotes are verbatim. All sources are linked. All absences are documented.

This is not interpretation. This is comparison of governmentâ€™s own words with governmentâ€™s own FOI responses.

If a document exists proving any claim on this page is inaccurate, please submit it via FOI requestâ€”because thatâ€™s the only way to make official records public.

Archive Note
As Hon Amanda Dorn stated in Parliament (18 Sept 2025):

â€œWhat is the point of any legislation changes if enforcement is not being enacted at the same time?â€

This page exists to document that enforcement was promised but never enactedâ€”and that FOI requests are the only mechanism forcing this truth into public record.
